awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Molecular signatures of aging in the primate hippocampus
awd_abstract_narration:
Primates are notable for their long, slow life histories and extended lifespans, a trend exaggerated in humans. The effects of this prolonged lifespan can be observed across the body, including the brain. While general patterns of brain aging are conserved among primates, there is clear variation in the pace of brain aging within and between species. In addition, humans are potentially more vulnerable to neurodegenerative diseases associated with the aging process; however, it is not clear what molecular mechanisms enable or shape this variation. This doctoral dissertation project characterizes molecular signatures of aging in the hippocampus of a non-human primate to identify conserved and derived features of primate brain aging and advance our understanding of potential evolved differences in humans that may increase our susceptibility to age-related brain disease. The project broadens the participation of graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented group in STEM, providing training, mentoring, and research experiences in bioinformatics and genomic analyses. In addition, with life expectancy increasing globally, this project addresses a specific global health concern by improving our understanding of the aging process at the molecular level and by contributing a valuable molecular dataset for future aging-related research.

The central hypothesis of this research is that gene regulation shapes hippocampal aging by mediating the interaction between a primate’s environment and biology across its lifespan. Objective 1 characterizes gene expression in the hippocampus of rhesus macaques across the lifespan using existing biosamples. These data are then integrated with previously generated matched DNA methylation data to identify differentially methylated regions that may regulate the expression of age-associated genes in the hippocampus. Objective 2 identifies microRNAs expressed in the hippocampus of rhesus macaques and characterizes their patterns of expression across the lifespan. These data are then integrated with matched gene expression data from Objective 1 to identify candidate miRNA-mRNA pairs and networks. To meet these objectives, matched mRNA and miRNA data are generated and analyzed for hippocampus samples using RNAseq and small RNAseq respectively. Importantly, this dataset includes both males and females and a range of ages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

In comparison to other species, many primates have long, slow life histories and extended lifespans. This is particularly true for humans where the effects of a prolonged lifespan can be observed in the brain as we age. While general patterns of brain aging are conserved among primates, there is clear variation in the pace of brain aging and vulnerability to diseases associated with the aging process within and between species. Which molecular mechanisms enable or shape this variation, however, remains unclear. This study addressed this gap in knowledge by characterizing molecular signatures of brain aging in the rhesus macaques, a close primate relative of humans. More specifically, we identified genes (mRNA and microRNA) and molecular processes that change with age in the hippocampus, a brain region particularly affected by the aging process. Importantly, our dataset included representation across adulthood allowing us to identify and characterize age-related patterns during midlife, a time period often underrepresented in studies of primate brain aging but important for shaping brain health outcomes later in life. By characterizing normal patterns of molecular aging in a closely related primate species, we are able to identify where humans deviate and how this might contribute to our increased susceptibility to neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's Disease). Additionally, the datasets and pipelines produced by this analysis will be of use to other researchers interested in examining molecular signatures of aging in other contexts or in explicitly testing their relationship to disease.

 

Broader Impact

With average life expectancy increasing globally, this project addresses a specific global health concern by improving our understanding of the aging process at the molecular level and by contributing a valuable molecular dataset for future aging-related research. More specifically, this research identified and characterized genes and pathways that change with age and may shape the aging process in longer-lived, larger-brain primates. These genes/pathways represent important candidates for intervention and future research.

The funded research also supported the training of a PhD candidate at the University of Oregon. As part of this study, the graduate student received advanced training in bioinformatics, genomics, statistics and data management and developed expertise in brain aging and aging biology more generally. Through this project he gained considerable experience presenting his research and was able to expand his research network through collaborations with numerous STEM professionals conducting innovative aging research. These skills and experiences have prepared him for STEM careers both in academia and industry. He continues to incorporate aspects of his research in his teaching, work as a research graduate employee and in his participation of science outreach events. In addition, this research has been used to support the training of an additional graduate student and two undergraduates in bioinformatics, genomics, statistics and aging, and has been used in undergraduate teaching at the University of Oregon. Importantly, this research increases capacity in a critical area of STEM research needed to better understand and support an aging population.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2024
Modified by: Kirstin N Sterner
